Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Anchoring Single Noble Metal Atoms for Better Catalysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
SusChEM: Anchoring Single Noble Metal Atoms/Clusters for Better Catalysis

This project, carried out by Jingyue (Jimmy) Liu at Arizona State University, addresses fundamental scientific concepts encountered in synthesizing single-atom catalysts, testing their efficacy, establishing their structure-function relationships, and developing new strategies to stabilize isolated, single atoms of active noble metals. Supported noble metal catalysts play a central role in energy conversion, chemical transformations, and the improved quality of our environment. Noble metals are, however, usually very expensive. The efficient use of noble metals is a critical factor in developing and applying noble metal catalysts. The atom efficiency and specific activity (i.e., activity per atom) generally increases with decreasing particle size, with the ultimate limit of size reduction that of a single atom. Dr. Liu's approach is to anchor the single atom onto nanostructured supports to immobilize them and prevent them from clustering together. The insights gained in this investigation are being used to guide the molecular design of next-generation catalysts for energy and environmental applications. The knowledge learned in this study promotes societal broader impact in fostering chemical sustainability by reducing the usage of limited and expensive raw materials and lowering the costs of goods. Broader impacts through education are offered in an annual Winter Workshop of High Resolution Electron Microscopy, attended primarily by graduate students, and through the John C. Wheatley Education and Outreach Facility dedicated to the promotion of scientific literacy in K-12 grade students.

With this award, the Chemical Catalysis Program in the Chemistry Division and the Solid State and Materials Program in the Division of Materials Science are jointly funding Dr. Jingyue (Jimmy) Liu from Arizona State University to conduct fundamental studies of structure and reactivity of supported noble metal single-atom catalysts (SACs) and epitaxially-anchored clusters. Dr. Liu's group focuses on developing SACs with high levels of metal loading and understanding the atom-support interactions, with a goal of stabilizing single noble metal atoms (Pt1, Au1, Pd1, Ir1 and Rh1) and nanoclusters on nanostructures of Fe3O4/Fe2O3 (reducible), Al2O3 (non-reducible), and ZnO (difficult to reduce) supports. The proposed catalytic reactions include Pd/ZnO for steam reforming of methanol to produce hydrogen, Ir/Fe3O4 (Fe2O3) and Au/Fe3O4 for the water-gas-shift reaction, and Pd/Al2O3, Pt/Al2O3 and Rh/Al2O3 for CO oxidation. Dr. Liu's group relies on aberration-corrected electron microscopic (ACEM) techniques, especially environmental ACEM, to identify unambiguously the distribution of isolated single noble metal atoms and epitaxial nanoclusters supported on high-surface-area supports and to follow the nanocluster movement under ambient gas pressure environments at elevated temperatures. Both in situ and ex situ catalytic reaction data are analyzed in detail to understand the synthesis-structure-property relationships of supported single atom and cluster catalysts with a particular emphasis on catalytic reactions relevant to energy conversion, chemical transformations, and environmental applications. Broader impacts through education are offered in an annual Winter Workshop of High Resolution Electron Microscopy, attended primarily by graduate students, and through the John C. Wheatley Education and Outreach Facility dedication to the promotion of scientific literacy in K-12 grade students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Catalysis plays a central role in energy conversion, chemical manufacturing and environmental remediation. Many industrial catalysts consist of noble metals dispersed on high-surface-area supports. The use of large amount of expensive and rare noble metals is not only costly but also unsustainable. Atom efficiency, a critical parameter in green chemistry and sustainable development, should be considered in designing future catalysts. Since catalysis occurs on surfaces downsizing metal particles to smaller sizes may significantly increase the efficiency of metal utilization. The recent advances in catalysis by atomically dispersed metal atoms opened new routes to designing not only highly active but also highly selective single-atom catalysts (SACs). The critical challenge to practical applications of SACs is, however, the sintering of metal atoms during a desired catalytic reaction, especially with high levels of metal loading.

Under the NSF award, " SusChEM: Anchoring Single Noble Metal Atoms for Better Catalysis", Dr. Liu’s research group focused on the structure-performance relationship of SACs, studied their long-term stability, and developed new strategies to anchor and localize supported metal atoms/clusters. They specifically focused: 1) how the redox capability of support affects performance of supported metal atoms; 2) how metal atoms sinter under different gas environment; 3) how support surface steps/edges anchor metal atoms to yield unique catalytic properties; 4) how polycrystalline, two-dimensional supports anchor high number density single metal atoms; 5) how functional nanoglues localize supported metal atoms/clusters and enhance their catalytic performance; and 6) how to reversibly transform supported metal atoms, clusters and single-atom chains for comparative studies of their catalytic properties. Dr. Liu’s group has clarified the role of the redox property of supports in controlling the activity of CO oxidation on supported Pt1 atoms and how the surface hydroxyl groups affect their performance. They have developed robust protocols to synthesize high metal loading SACs (> 1 atom/nm2) and conducted intensive investigations on the stability of supported metal atoms under various gas environments that are relevant for CO oxidation, water-gas-shift (WGS) reaction, preferential oxidation of CO in H2 rich stream (PROX), and hydrogenation reactions. Under oxidative environment, supported metal atoms/clusters are generally stable; under highly reducing environment, however, metal atoms sinter to form nanoclusters/particles. Based on the knowledge gained from these studies, they developed step/edge anchored metal SACs that either provide extremely high activity or 100% selectivity for liquid phase selective hydrogenation reactions. They constructed a “pocket” like Rh1/MoS2 SAC that mimics the functions of enzymes to yield selective hydrogenation of unsaturated aldehydes to unsaturated alcohols with 100% selectivity. To anchor high number density metal atoms they developed 2D supports (e.g., Co3O4 and ZnO nanosheets) with abundant surface steps and grain boundaries to anchor metal atoms. Since strongly anchoring metal atoms may adversely affect their activity or selectivity they developed a new approach to preventing sintering of supported metal atoms/clusters: Use functional nanoglues to localize atomically dispersed metal atoms/clusters. They have developed various types of functional nanoglues and will apply the nanoglue-based SACs to catalytic reactions that require highly reducing environment. Finally, Dr. Liu’s group has developed a facile and scalable synthesis protocol to reversibly produce ZnO nanowire supported single Ir atoms, subnano clusters and single-atom size Ir chains. Such capability of reversibly transforming different configurations of supported metal atoms/clusters provides a powerful platform for studying structure-performance relationships of supported metal species for catalytic reactions. The knowledge gained and nanostructures/nanoarchitectures developed can be applied to broad research fields beyond heterogeneous catalysis.

In addition to the fundamental knowledge and skills gained through this research project, postdoctoral associates, graduate/undergraduate students, and high school students were trained in the art and science of research and were prepared to carry out independent research in areas vital to technological advancement. In particular, graduate students worked on this project learned how to design critical experiments, analyze data, and draft technical reports; undergraduate students learned the importance of scientific research and how innovative research can benefit society; and high school students learned the importance of STEM and nanoscience.  The knowledge gained in this study clearly promoted societal broader impact in fostering chemical sustainability by reducing the usage of limited and expensive raw materials and lowering the costs of goods. Dr. Liu has incorporated the learnings gained through this research project into the annual Winter School of High Resolution Electron Microscopy and the curriculum of the Professional Science Master’s in Nanoscience Program as well as the broad communities by giving numerous scientific presentations. The research accomplishments through this NSF award have been reported in 33 peer reviewed journal publications and 18 peer reviewed conference proceedings. In addition to these accomplishments, there are several manuscripts being under peer review or to be submitted.
